audio_caption: The audio clip begins with the sound of a clinking mug or glass, followed by a male speaker with a casual tone who states, "There may be bugs in some of these mugs but there ain't no mugs on Jake." Another male voice, also with a conversational tone, then identifies them as Jimmy and Jake and refers to "the Weekly Dumb," mentioning a successful "Jeff Passen Day." They acknowledge this success and the breaking of news stories. The clip ends with a brief, upbeat, synthesized musical interlude.

The clip begins with a male speaker acknowledging a topic of discussion, then noting his dog Mazie has bad gas. After that, a sigh can be heard. The same male speaker expresses his agreement with a statement, and then recalls that last night, someone mentioned the smell of poop, attributing the odor to the dog's flatulence. A dog bark concludes the clip.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing his mild disgust over finding "poop" outside his bedroom, followed by an exchange with another person, possibly female, who is trying to be positive about the situation. The tone is casual. The first male speaker then transitions into a discussion about sports news, specifically mentioning Albert Pujols joining the Los Angeles Dodgers. The tone becomes more enthusiastic and sports-oriented. The conversation continues with further analysis of the move, including details about how Pujols plays and team dynamics. Later in the clip, there is the sound of an alarm, potentially a buzzer or notification. The analysis of the news continues further.

The clip starts with a male speaker, in an enthusiastic tone, discussing Albert's potential playoff role. A second male voice then chimes in with a friendly tone, referencing Placido Polanco's connection to the Dodgers and mentioning that his head is the best ever. The first speaker then reiterates the claim that he has the best head ever, leading to a brief interjection by the second speaker stating, "Oh," in a disappointed tone, as the first speaker says "that sucks".

The audio clip starts with two speakers, likely both male, discussing participation in some event. One asks, "Are we doing this or we just going?", and the other confirms with some hesitancy, followed by a discussion about rules or parameters, with the first speaker asking about "chugging race" and "dugout mugs". Preparations are made, with one speaker suggesting, "Do you want me to put a timer on?", before another says, "Zack's putting the timer on." A brief countdown leads into loud, upbeat music with a comedic tone, featuring horns and what seems like a low-quality recording. After the music stops, a male speaker claims, "I think I beat him to the table," followed by commentary about sink water and its taste. The first speaker expresses disgust, then extends thanks to "Dugout Mugs," and concludes with a callout by name, before planning the "next segment" with the instruction to "put the tape on that Zack".

The clip begins with a male speaker announcing the next segment as "almost a breakdown." His tone is excited and jovial as he introduces the topic of a basketball play by the Nets, comparing it to a pool game among friends, suggesting it involves a series of tips leading to a slam-in, with potential "accidents." He emphasizes that the group's perseverance makes the celebration better and contrasts perfection with the excitement of slight missteps. The speaker playfully describes scenarios where the ball bounces off unexpected objects, maintaining an energetic and humorous tone. He is followed by a second male speaker, seemingly in agreement with the points made, as well as the interjection of a third male, providing brief commentary, before the clip ends.

The audio clip begins with one male speaker recalling an event. The second male speaker agrees, describing a specific part of the event and how the Cavs "played along." The first male speaker elaborates, "they started it." He details the play, highlighting Blake Griffin's "scoop behind the back toss." He concludes that it was a "really cool play". The second male speaker responds with "that was talking nets." The clip concludes with a buzzer sound.

The clip begins with two speakers, both male, cheerfully transitioning from one topic to another, referencing "talking nets" and suggesting to move to sports. The second speaker introduces a story about a pitcher's stolen arm, which is met with shock from the first speaker. The second speaker then confirms the outrageous claim in an affirmative tone.

The clip begins with two male speakers discussing a college baseball player whose backpack, containing his prosthetic arm, was stolen. They mention the player's name, Jim Abbott, and his university, Augustana. Their tone is conversational and slightly humorous. As the dialogue continues, a burst of upbeat, folky music plays featuring a male voice singing what sounds like the lyrics "I think I'll go to Boston." The music fades out, and the speakers resume their conversation. One of them asks, "Jim, where did they find this arm?" The conversation ends, with the second man replying, "in his backpack."

The audio clip starts with a conversational tone as a male speaker continues a thought mentioning thieves throwing something in a recycling plant and someone finding an arm. A second male speaker then says he wants a mic-ed up conversation with the thieves as they go through the backpack saying "what we get? what we get?". The first speaker asks if "fair or foul" about the thieves finding an arm and questioning whether they would go to the recycling plant or put it in lost and found. The second speaker responds that the thieves would say "we didn't steal his arm. We stole his shit. Be fair when you're covering it." A brief pause, then another speaker replies, "Do we want the arms?" A short pause, followed by conversational tone as the speakers briefly discuss resell value. A final speaker states anyone that keeps a prosthetic arm in their car for no reason is weird, followed by acknowledgement, then a realization "that's what you meant when you threw it to me."

The clip starts with one male speaker humorously recounting an experience of having a mannequin hand in his glove compartment since high school. He mentions being pulled over by a cop who reached for his gun upon seeing the hand, followed by the speaker explaining that he sometimes uses it at drive-throughs, causing his "hand to fall off," seemingly in jest. Another male speaker interjects to comment on how he and his "tall friends" had sex in college.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker describing a story about someone named Jimmy who went around for a weekend with "full mannequin hands" and introduced himself to girls. The speaker imitates a potential negative reaction from the girls. A second male speaker chimes in, humorously imagining the dilemma of whether the person is a "dickhead" with a fake hand or actually has a prosthetic. The first speaker interjects with the question of whether to "play along with this." He then gives a shoutout to Parker Hansen. The second speaker then briefly says, "Some uh," before the clip ends.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing "great non-sports" and mentioning the pandemic. A second male speaker responds, remarking about "court zoom calls". The audio then abruptly transitions into music, likely a musical interlude.

A man speaks enthusiastically about his friend Nathaniel Saxton logging into virtual traffic court, remarking that the system sometimes saves old zoom names. He explains that his friend Nathaniel logged in as "buttfucker 3000", admitting his sister set the name. A woman's voice sternly says: "Your name's not buttfucker 3000, you yoho". The man explains that the judge asked "So your name isn't buttfucker 3000?". A man is then heard chuckling, seemingly unaware what is happening, before speaking in a high-pitched tone, the original male speaker exclaims "Be cool, man!" The man who was chuckling says "What did you hear about me? Like, what?". The initial speaker says: "It's a common parking ticket". Another man exclaims "Ha!". The initial speaker comments on not knowing why the judge is calling you buttfucker 3000 and saying "Wait, like what?". Finally, he states that the judge put him in timeout.

The clip starts with a male speaker quoting what someone said, labeling them an idiot and a yo-yo, followed by the original speaker addressing the judge and apologizing, mentioning "airplane name" and calling it an inside joke. The judge curtly responds with "well, you should be." Energetic, upbeat music starts, resembling a playful and slightly electronic style, along with a male voice excitedly announcing "Employee of the Week." The voice names Mr. Nolan, a high school social studies teacher who apparently taught the speaker everything they know. Another male speaker mentions emailing him and wanting him on a show, because all of their good memories come from Mr. Nolan's class. But he "don't want to come on your show."

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing gratitude for someone reaching out. He repeats the phrase "thanks for reaching out." Then he states, "No interest," and asks to not be emailed again. He clarifies he didn't say it directly, but implied it and emphasizes it with "you felt it". Another male speaker concurs with "you felt it in the email." The first speaker mentions receiving two emails despite not responding to the first.

A male speaker starts by saying, "Yeah." He describes an incident, stating that "there better not be a third and no, I don't want to come on your show." He also mentions that the "old story is from J.J.R".
He then continues to share his experience, saying that he could have returned with one cheeky remark. He later adds, "I put you in my rearview, please stop emailing me." He ends the first section by sarcastically yelling, "You guys ruined my life for a year."

After a brief comedic break, a playful male voice announces "That was a weekly dumb," as a plastic bag rustling noise, perhaps being crumpled, is heard. 
Next, there is a short promotional message for "Dugout Mugs", including a code to get a discount off MLB "Dugout Mugs".

Finally, there is some upbeat music playing. The male singer is trying to figure out a tweet he saw and is looking for it. He mentions a "Placido Polanco" and states that he "nailed it".
